channel.title: HTML & CSS Tip of the Week

item.title: A few fun nesting tips & tricks
item.description: There are some handy things that you can do with nesting, espcially when you start moving the & placeholder around!

item.title: One corner, two border radii
item.description: Did you know you can control the border radius of both sides of a corner indepenently of one another? It might seem a little strange to do, but you can do some intersting things with it!

item.title: The picture element
item.description: Sometimes, designs have different images for large and small screen layouts. In those situations, it can be tempting to simply bring in multiple images and use a media query in your CSS to control when we see each one, but the <picture> element is purpose-built for these situations.

item.title: Single-colour gradients
item.description: It might seem strange, but single-colour gradients can come in handy in a few different ways!

item.title: @property
item.description: Register custom CSS properties with specific syntax to enable smooth animations and transitions.

item.title: :nth-last-child
item.description: Select elements by counting backwards from the end using the :nth-last-child pseudo-class selector.

item.title: object-fit and object-position
item.description: Crop images in a similar to way background images by using object-fit and object-position

item.title: calc-size()
item.description: We can now do calculations based on the intrinsic size of an element

item.title: The ::selection-pseudo-element
item.description: Add a little personality to your site by changing the selection styles

item.title: The <output> element
item.description: Display calculation results and user interaction outcomes with semantic HTML using the output element.

item.title: :first-child and :last-child
item.description: Style the first and last elements in a group without needing extra classes or JavaScript.

item.title: The datalist element
item.description: Create autocomplete dropdowns with suggestions using the datalist element without JavaScript.

item.title: :out-of-range
item.description: A quick look at the :not-in-range psuedo-class.

item.title: :placeholder-shown
item.description: A quick look at the :placeholder-shown pseudo-class for styling form elements that are displaying placeholder text.

item.title: interpolate-size: allow-keywords
item.description: Animate and transition to auto, and other intrinsic keyword values.

item.title: input type='color'
item.description: Easily add a color picker to your page using an input with a type of color.

item.title: :only-child
item.description: Learn how to use the :only-child selector to style elements differently when they have no siblings. Perfect for adaptive designs with optional elements like figure captions. Plus, see how combining it with :has() creates powerful parent styling possibilities.

item.title: The min() and max() functions
item.description: The CSS min() and max() functions can be powerful alternatives to clamp() for responsive layouts.

item.title: The <q> element
item.description: When creating quotes in HTML, most people are aware of the <blockquote> element, but for shorter quotes you might want an inline element, and that is where the <q> element comes in

item.title: input type="number"
item.description: Number inputs can be useful, but they aren't as straight forward as they might seem at first.

item.title: :in-range pseudo-class
item.description: Style inputs based on if the value is within specific range limits

item.title: The search element
item.description: A quick look at the search element, a semantic element for search and filtering

item.title: The :has() pseudo-selector
item.description: The :has() relational selector allows you to select parents of elements, but also preceding elements, siblings, and much more!

item.title: Transitioning to and from display: none
item.description: Two new CSS features, @starting-style and allow-discrete, making it quite easy to transition to and from display: none!

item.title: The :focus-visible pseudo-class
item.description: :focus-visible is an improved version of :focus, meaning we don't have to fight those focus rings

item.title: Container query units: cqi and cqb
item.description: Responsive units that respond to local sizes, rather than the entire viewport

item.title: min-width: fit-content
item.description: Text wraps, but only as a last resort!

item.title: The :user-valid pseudo-class
item.description: A new and improved version of :valid that only kicks in once the user has interacted with the field

item.title: The <kbd> element
item.description: An underused HTML element for when we want to show keyboard commands and user inputs.

item.title: The :empty pseudo-class
item.description: We can use CSS to find elements that don't have any content in them.
